newsitem.title: UK: INSIGHT - Dlr/yen shaky as major 110 support looms.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - Dlr/yen shaky as major 110 support looms.

text.p: Dollar/yen remains weak and looks set to test strong support around 110 yen after falling to its lowest level since November 1996, technical analysts said.

"Dollar/yen has major support in the 110/109 area, and I expect it to go to 110 where it might form a major bottom for a strong recovery," said Stefan Steinemann, technical analyst at Lloyds Bank in Geneva.
At 0755 GMT the dollar was at 110.70/80, down from 112.43/53 in late European trading on Tuesday. Dollar/mark was at 1.7130/40 from 1.7186/93.

Despite its rapid decline the dollar has strong support below 111 yen, chartists said. The lower boundary of an ascending trend channel, drawn from the all-time low at 79.76 of April 1995, cuts in at 110.80. Below there, a solid prop is at 110.65, an Elliot wave support.
Below 110, the dollar has support in the 109.20 area, a 38.2 percent Fibonacci retracement of its entire move from the record lows to the 1997 high of 127.46 on May 1.
Alan Dunne, technical analyst at Bank of America, said the move below the previous low at 111.85 confirmed the formation of a bear flag, setting up a target at 108 and then 106.
Dollar/mark also looks poised to extend its decline from the 1.7210 high on Tuesday but has support in the 1.7085/50 band, an area of dense congestion dating back to May.

"The dollar is likely to test support at 1.7050 but recover from there," said Steinemann. He sees critical support at 1.7020, which if eroded would signal a sharp dollar sell-off to 1.6800. The 1.7020 level is this week's cycle low from Monday.
Eddie Matts, director at Capital Management, said the loss of 1.7110 deferred the uptrend and a final drop to 1.6850.
Upticks face resistance at 1.7160 and 1.7275, a 61.8 percent retracement of the previous decline from 1.7423.
